Dresker v. Stop & Shop, 635 N.E.2d 5 (Ma.proposition: The Defendant owed a duty of care to Plaintiff as a business invitee to maintain its premises in a safe condition.
Dresker v. Stop & Shop, 635 N.E.2d 5 (Ma.support_reasoning: The reproduced opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case involving a murder conviction and jury instructions on malice and intoxication. It does not involve premises liability, business invitees, or any duty of care owed by a business to a customer. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that a defendant owed a duty of care as a business invitee to maintain premises in a safe condition; the citation is inapposite for that proposition.
Dresker v. Stop & Shop, 635 N.E.2d 5 (Ma.relevant_excerpt: The defendant, tried on an indictment charging murder in the first degree, appeals from his conviction of second degree murder, claiming the judge erred in instructing the jury... Following a proper instruction on first degree murder and the capacity of proof of intoxication to reduce that crime to murder in the second degree, the judge gave the following instruction...

Murphy v. Boston Ice Co., 52 N.E. 505 (M.raw_text: Murphy v. Boston Ice Co., 52 N.E. 505 (Mass. 1899)
Murphy v. Boston Ice Co., 52 N.E. 505 (M.proposition: The Defendant owed a duty of care to Plaintiff as a business invitee to maintain its premises in a safe condition.
Murphy v. Boston Ice Co., 52 N.E. 505 (M.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an ex post facto challenge to an indeterminate sentencing statute and the effect on deductions for good behavior; it does not involve premises liability, business invitees, or any duty of care owed to someone on the defendant’s property. The defendant is the Commonwealth in a criminal case, not a business premises owner, and the court never discusses invitee status or maintenance of premises. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for a duty-of-care rule for business invitees.
Murphy v. Boston Ice Co., 52 N.E. 505 (M.relevant_excerpt: The statutes applying to the petitioner’s case which were in force when he committed the offences of which he was convicted are Pub. Sts. c. 222, §§ 20, 21, 22, and St. 1884, c. 152. … The petitioner contends that the effect of these differences may be to make the term of imprisonment longer than it would have been under the laws in force at the time the offences were committed, and to change his position in other respects to his disadvantage, and that therefore the statute is unconstitutional and void.

Carney v. Big Y Foods, Inc., 997 N.E.2d.raw_text: Carney v. Big Y Foods, Inc., 997 N.E.2d 86 (Mass. 2000)
Carney v. Big Y Foods, Inc., 997 N.E.2d.proposition: The Defendant owed a duty of care to Plaintiff as a business invitee to maintain its premises in a safe condition.
Carney v. Big Y Foods, Inc., 997 N.E.2d.case_name: Michael A. Lane v. State of Indiana
Carney v. Big Y Foods, Inc., 997 N.E.2d.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about murder, lesser-included offenses, evidentiary rulings, and Confrontation Clause issues. It does not involve premises liability, business invitees, or a land possessor’s duty of care to maintain premises in a safe condition. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that a defendant owed a duty of care to a plaintiff as a business invitee.
